messages.message:
Got an update - adding `reorient_words: true` to the OCR config fixed the negative coordinate issue. However, they followed up with:

```but we have another issue now with coordinates for wrong image.. First line coordinate matching with 3rd an 4th line of the OCR text.
 
Suppose I have image in right rotation, I run through the OCR and capture the OCR text and OCR locations of each word.
Same image I rotated by 180 degree, I run through the OCR and capture the OCR and OCR location. Ideally coordinates of the OCR text word should be same which I got it from step #1 but currently same is not same
 
I have same issue with HQ an MARX both.```
Basically, if they rotate the image themselves ahead of time, they aren’t getting the same coordinates than if they do it using us.
@Jonathan Shih @Chetan @Aaron Tami Is the answer here “Yeah, sorry we use a different method of flipping images 180° but tough noogies, that’s just how it is”?
when we do rotation, we adjust the coordinates differently than when we don't do rotation
the relative coordinates of all the words should be the same (relative to each other that is), but not the absolute coordinates... if that makes sense
Hrrm. Ok, so my answer stands? “Tough noogies!” :smile: (That’s perfectly fine, just want to clarify before I let them down gently)
ya, curious why they would want the coordinate systems to be the exact same?
when we do rotation, we usually cut off any excess whitespace
I’ll reply with all that, and include a “Why is this a problem?”

@Aaron Tami Please review to make sure I’m not lying to our customer (I hate when I do that):
```Good Morning Rohit,

So that I understand, the issue is that when you rotate an image ahead of time and run it through OCR, you get different coordinates than when _we_ rotate the image and then OCR it. Is that correct?

If so, I believe it is happening because we trim whitespace on rotated images, as well as using a slightly different algorithm to adjust the coordinates. However, the *relative* coordinates of all the words should be identical, though not the absolute coordinates.

If that approach doesn't work for your use case, please let me know what that use case is, and we will see what we can do to help.

Thanks,

David```
Going to go ahead and send this. If I was wrong on any particular, lemme know and I can correct.
